metadata.title: Silanization of Iron Oxide Magnetic Nanoparticles with ionic liquids based on amino acids and its application as heterogeneous catalysts for Knoevenagel condensation reactions

Fig. 2 Fig. 3 XRD patterns of MNPs and stabilized MNPs with ionic liquid. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 TEM micrographs of a) MNPs, b) Chol-MNPs, c) Lys-Chol-MNPs and Gly-Chol-MNPs. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Thermogravimetric analysis of A) Chol-MNPs and B) Lys-Chol-MNPs. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Differential pulse voltammograms of MNPs and MNPs stabilized with ionic liquids. Cathodic (A) and anodic differential pulse voltammograms (B) (25 and 75 mV Modulation Amplitude) immediately after immersion of the MCPE in aqueous Tris buffer pH 6.4 as electrolyte vs Ag/AgCl/KCl (3 M) as reference electrode. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Cyclic voltammograms of MNPs, Gly-Chol-MNPs and Chol-MNPS (com) materials (10% ratio to graphite) immediately after immersion of the MCPE in aqueous Tris buffer pH 6.4 as electrolyte vs Ag/AgCl/KCl (3 M) as reference electrode (100 mV/s scan speed). Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Catalytic activity of Chol-MNPs in consecutive reaction cycles of Knoevenagel condensation reaction. Fig. 8 Table 1 Particle sizes for samples, as determined with the Scherrer formula from peak breadth measurements for the different reflections spanning the corresponding X-ray diffraction patterns. Table 1 Material Particle Size (nm) MNPs 9 Chol-MNPs 13 Gly-Chol-MNPs 11 Lys-Chol-MNPs 10 Chol-MNPs (commercial) 9 Table 2 Knoevenagel condensation reaction catalysed by ionic liquid stabilized magnetic nanoparticles a . Table 2 Entry Catalyst Substrate Time(h) % Conversion b % Yield c 1 Chol-MNPs Malononitrile d 0.5 100 98 2 Gly-Chol-MNPs 0.5 100 96 3 Lys-Chol-MNPs 0.5 100 97 4 Chol-MNPs (com) 0.5 100 96 5 Chol-MNPs Ethyl cyanoacetate e 24 84 79 6 Chol-MNPs f 24 – 54 7 Chol-MNPs (com) 24 79 71 8 Gly-Chol g 24 – 88 9 Lys-Chol-MNPs 24 65 61 10 Gly-Chol-MNPs 24 67 62 a Reaction conditions: 50 mg of catalyst, at room temperature, 11 mmol of RCH2CN and 11 mmol of benzaldehyde and Ethanol as solvent (5 mL final volume). b Conversion vs malononitrile or ethyl cyanoacetate (GC values). c Yield of the isolated product identified by 1H NMR spectroscopy. d Selectivity value is 100% towards 2-benzylidenemalonitrile. e Selectivity value is 99% towards ethyl 2-cyano-3-phenylacrylate; traces of benzoic are observed. f Reaction under solventless conditions. g 2% w/w ratio (catalyst/substrate). Silanization of Iron Oxide Magnetic Nanoparticles with ionic liquids based on amino acids and its application as heterogeneous catalysts for Knoevenagel condensation reactions Isabel del Hierro ⁎ Yolanda Pérez ⁎ Mariano Fajardo Departamento de Biología y Geología, Física y Química Inorgánica, Escuela Superior de Ciencias Experimentales y Tecnología, Universidad Rey Juan Carlos, 28933, Móstoles, Madrid, Spain Departamento de Biología y Geología, Física y Química Inorgánica Escuela Superior de Ciencias Experimentales y Tecnología Universidad Rey Juan Carlos Móstoles Madrid 28933 Spain ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Iron oxide magnetic nanoparticles (MNPs) stabilized with silane ligands, containing choline hydroxide and amino acid ionic liquid functionalities, have been prepared. The appropriate silane ligands have been synthesized; the choline hydroxide propyl silane ligand in a process inspired in the industrial production of choline hydroxide and the amino acid ionic liquids in a straight forward acid-base process using the former compound. The synthesized materials have been fully characterized by elemental analysis, X-ray diffraction (XRD), fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRUV-vis), thermogravimetric analysis (TG-DTG), N2 adsorption-desorption, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and voltammetry solid state techniques. Ionic liquid stabilized magnetic nanoparticles have been very effective as heterogeneous basic catalysts in Knoevenagel condensation reaction at room temperature. The catalyst containing choline hydroxide ionic liquid (Chol-MNPs) exhibited highest catalytic activity and can easily be recovered under an external magnetic field and subsequently reused several times. Keywords Amino acid Ionic liquid Magnetic nanoparticles Knoevenagel condensation 1 Introduction The synthesis of pharmaceutical and fine chemicals by methods inspired by green chemistry principles is still a challenge. The search of new heterogeneous Brönsted-type basic catalysts able to perform green chemistry condensation reactions with high activity and selectivity values is gaining prominence in order to overcome the drawbacks of their classical homogenous inorganic counterparts, KOH and NaOH [1]. Magnetic nanoparticles have found a broad range of applications as support due to their interesting properties [2,3,4]. Various methods to prepare MNPs are available [5], but the co precipitation technique is probably the easiest and most efficient chemical pathway. The use of surfactants to stabilize these synthesized nanoparticles is critical, as Fe3O4 nanoparticles have high surface energies and tend to aggregate. They also have high chemical reactivity and are easily oxidized to Fe2O3, causing loss of magnetism. Magnetic particles can be stabilized by electrostatic and steric repulsions by using inorganic supports or polymers as surface coatings [6,7]. Several studies have been published on the synthesis and characterization of magnetite nanoparticles with basic amino groups on the surface. Pinteala and co-workers [8] have synthesized hydrophilic magnetite particles by employing a two-step method: in the first step magnetite particles with hydrophobic shell were formed in presence of oleic acid–oleylamine complex through a synthesis in mass, without solvent; while in the second step the hydrophobic shell was interchanged with an aminosilane monomer. Yamaura et al. [9] have performed a direct silanization procedure in an acidic aqueous to deposit aminopropylalkoxysilane on the surface of the magnetite core. He and co-workers [10] have published a complete kinetic study of this process based on grafting density calculated by TGA studies. Tetramethylammonium hydroxide has also been used to stabilize nanoparticles of magnetite by a direct reduction precipitation method [11]. It is noteworthy that in many cases the protecting outer shells not only stabilize the nanoparticles, but can also be used for further functionalization, for instance, with other nanoparticles or various ligands, depending on the desired application. In this context, the development of solid base catalysts as heterogeneous catalysts and the use of ionic liquids able to act as both basic catalyst and stabilizer of “naked” metal NPs should be a useful strategy [12]. In this study, we have designed and synthesized iron oxide magnetic nanoparticles, stabilized with silane ligands, containing choline hydroxide ionic liquid and choline amino acid ionic liquid. In addition, the surface of these stabilized magnetic nanoparticles has been characterized by XRD, FT-IR, TGA, UV–vis and electrochemical solid-state studies and their morphology determined by TEM microscopy. We have tested these materials as heterogeneous basic catalysts in Knoevenagel condensation of benzaldehyde with malononitrile or ethyl cyanoacetate at room temperature. Different reaction conditions and the effect of choline amino acid have been studied and possible reaction mechanism have been proposed. Reusability tests have also been performed and the stability of recovered catalyst has been demonstrated. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials When required, the reactions were performed using standard Schlenk tube techniques under an atmosphere of dry nitrogen. Sodium hydroxide 97% and hydrochloric acid 35% were purchased from Panreac. Iron(II) sulphate heptahydrate (FeSO4·7H2O) 99.5% and iron(III) chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3·6H2O) 95% were purchased from Scharlau. 3-Glycidyloxypropyl)trimethoxysilane, trimethylamine solution 4.2 M in ethanol, glycine, lysine, malononitrile, ethyl cyanoacetate and benzaldehyde were purchased from Sigma Aldrich and used as received. Milli-Q water was used in the experiments when required. Ethanol was purchased from VWR. Toluene and chloroform were purchased from Scharlau and VWR respectively, distilled and dried before use according to conventional literature methods. Water was obtained from a Millipore Milli-Q system (Waters, USA). 2.2 Preparation of catalysts 2.2.1 Synthesis of silane ligand containing choline hydroxide ionic liquid (OH-Chol) Trimethylamine (4.2 M) in ethanol (1.2 mL, 5.0 mmol) was added by syringe over an aqueous solution of 3-glycidyloxypropyl)trimethoxysilane (1 mL, 4.52 mmol) and the mixture stirred 2 h at room temperature. Finally, water and ethanol were removed under reduced pressure to obtain a pale-yellow oil. 1H NMR (400 MHz, D2O, 25°C): δ = 0.36 (m, 2H, Si-CH 2-), 1.51 (m, 2H, Si-CH2 CH 2−), 3.38 (m, 2H, Si-CH2 CH2 CH 2−), 3.07 (s, 9H, N-(CH3)3), 3.39 (m, 2H, −OCH 2−), 4.26 (m, 1H, −CH-OH), 3.34 (m, 2H, −CH 2 N). 13 C{H}-NMR (400 MHz, D2O, 25 °C): δ = 9.7 (Si-CH2-), 23.2 (Si-CH2-CH2-), 72.0 (Si-CH2 CH2-CH2-), 54.2 (N-(CH3)3), 74.3 (-O-CH2-), 68.5 (−CHOH), 64.8 (−CH2 N). (See Fig. S1) 2.2.2 Synthesis of silane ligands containing choline amino acid ionic liquid (Gly-Chol and Lys-Chol) In a typical synthesis: an aqueous solution of the silane ligand containing choline hydroxide ionic liquid, freshly prepared, was added over an aqueous solution of the amino acid (glycine or lysine), maintaining an equimolar ratio. The mixture was stirred for 24 h at room temperature and water was removed under reduce pressure, first using a rotary evaporator (60 °C, 15 min), and then in vacuo to yield a sticky pale yellow solid. Ionic liquid with glycine (Gly-Chol); 1H NMR (400 MHz, D2O, 25°C): δ = 0.44 (m, 2H, SiCH 2 ), 1.50 (m, 2H, SiCH2 CH 2-), 3.34 (m, 2H, Si-CH2 CH2 CH 2-), 3.04 (s, 9H, N(CH3)3), 3.35 (m, 2H, −OCH 2-), 4.22 (m, 1H, −CH OH), 3.28 (m, 2H, −CH 2 N). 3.13 (s, 2H, COOCH 2 NH2). 13 C{H}-NMR (400 MHz, D2O, 25 °C): δ = 8.8 (Si-CH2-), 22.6 (SiCH2- CH2−), 72.1 (Si-CH2 CH2-CH2-), 54.4 (N-(CH3)3), 73.9 (−O CH2−), 68.4 (-CHOH), 64.8 (-CH2 N), 43.4 (COO-CH2 NH2). 178.1 (COO-CH2 NH2). Ionic liquid with lysine (Lys-Chol); 1H NMR (400 MHz, D2O, 25°C): δ = 0.31 (m, 2H, Si-CH 2-), 1.51 (m, 2H, Si-CH2 CH 2-), 3.34 (m, 2H, Si-CH2 CH2 CH 2 ), 3.03 (s, 9H, N-(CH3)3), 3.34 (m, 2H, −OCH 2-), 4.20 (m, 1H, −CH OH), 3.26 (m, 2H, −CH 2 N). 3.78 (m, 2H, COOCHR-NH2); 1.32-1-34, 1.49, 2.57 (m/t, 2H, COOCH(NH2)−CH 2 CH 2 CH 2 CH 2 NH2) 13 C{H}-NMR (400 MHz, D2O, 25 °C): δ = 9.5 (Si-CH2-), 22.3 (Si-CH2-CH2-), 72.0 (Si-CH2 CH2 CH2-), 54.2 (N-(CH3)3), 74.2 (−O CH2−), 68.5 (−CHOH), 64.8 (−CH2 N), 57.5 (COO−CHR−NH2), 39.9, 29.6, 34.2, 55.9 (COOCH(NH2)-CH2-CH2-CH2-CH2 NH2), 183.3 (COO CH2 NH2). (See Fig. S2 and S3). 2.2.3 Synthesis of iron oxide magnetic nanoparticles (MNPs) An aqueous solution of NaOH (400 mL, 0.5 M) was deoxygenated by bubbling nitrogen for 30 min. FeCl3·6H2O (1.89 g, 7 mmol) and FeSO4·2H2O (1.94 g, 7 mmol) were dissolved in 30 and 45 mL water, respectively. The two solutions were mixed and added into the alkaline solution, previously prepared, dropwise under vigorous stirring. The reaction was heated to 80 °C and stirred for 30 min under nitrogen atmosphere. The black solid obtained was washed with milliQ water (3 × 50 mL) and dried under vacuum. 2.2.4 Stabilization of MNPs with ionic liquids The MNPs obtained by co-precipitation (0.25 g) were dispersed in water (50 mL) and an aqueous solution of ionic liquid (OHChol, Gly-Chol or Lys-Chol) (2 mmol), previously synthesized, was added under mechanical stirring. The reaction was stirred and heated at 80 °C for 2 h and the stabilized magnetic nanoparticles separated by centrifugation or magnetic decantation and washed with ethanol. The samples denoted as Chol-MNPs, Gly-Chol-MNPs and Lys-Chol-MNPs were dried under vacuum and stored. 2.3 Characterization X-Ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the silicas were obtained on a Phillips Diffractometer model PW3040/00 X’Pert MPD/MRD at 45 KV and 40 mA, using Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). N2 gas adsorption-desorption isotherms were obtained using a Micromeritics TriStar 3000 analyser, and pore size distributions were calculated using the Barret-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) model on the adsorption branch. Infrared spectra were recorded on a Nicolet-550 FT-IR spectrophotometer (in the region 4000–400 cm−1) as KBr disks. 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a Varian Mercury FT-400 spectrometer. The DRUV-vis spectroscopic measurements were carried out on a Varian Cary-500 spectrophotometer equipped with an integrating sphere and polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) as reference, with d = 1 g cm−3 and thickness of 6 mm. Thermogravimetric analysis was performed using a Setsys 18 A (Setaram) thermogravimetric analyzer. Elemental analyses were carried out by the Microanalytical Service of the Universidad Complutense de Madrid. The C, H and N analysis was accomplished by combustion analysis with elemental microanalyzers LECO CHNS-932. 2.4 Modified carbon paste electrode preparation The modified carbon paste electrodes (MCPE) used as working electrode were prepared by mixing with a pestle in an agate mortar the iron oxide nanoparticles materials under study with graphite (Metrohm) (10% (w,w) ratio) and mineral oil as agglutinant (Sigma-Aldrich) until a uniform paste was obtained. The material was then packed into the end of a Teflon cylindrical tube equipped with a screwing stainless steel piston providing an inner electrical contact. All the initial electrode activity could always be restored by simply removing the outer layer of paste by treatment with polishing paper. 2.5 Knoevenagel condensation reaction In a typical experiment, 11 mmol of benzaldehyde, 11 mmol of ethyl cyanoacetate and 50 mg of catalyst (Chol-MNPs, Gly-Chol-MNPs o Lys-Chol-MNPs) in ethanol (5 mL) were mixed in a 50 mL tube and the mixture was stirred at room temperature. After reaction completion 10 mL of dichloromethane were added to dilute and solubilize the organic compounds. The solid catalyst was precipitated by centrifugation or magnetic decantation and separated from the liquid phase. To analyse the sample by gas chromatography 1 mL of sample was withdrawn and diluted in ethanol to 5 mL and a fixed amount of dodecane as external standard. The sample was analysed by GC-FID (Agilent 6890N, DB-Wax capillary column 30 m, 0.53 mm). In addition, the corresponding compounds obtained after carbon–carbon condensations reactions was recrystallized from ethyl acetate and checked by 1H NMR spectroscopy (See Fig. S1, S2 and S3). 2.6 Reusability test After the completion of reaction, the Chol-MNPs catalyst was easily recovered under an external magnetic field, washed with dichloromethane (5 mL), and reused several times without further treatment under the experimental conditions previously described. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization The industrial production of choline hydroxide includes reacting at a temperature above 30 °C, ethylene oxide, trimethylamine and water in the presence of an aqueous medium [13]. Similarly, here we have prepared a silane ligand containing choline hydroxide functionality from 3-glycidyloxypropyl)trimethoxysilane and trimethylamine with epoxide opening and the subsequent quaternization of the amine. In a straight forward acid base process, the choline hydroxide function was neutralized with an equimolar amount of amino acid (glycine or lysine) (See Scheme 1 ) MNPs were prepared via co-precipitation of Fe2+ and Fe3+ ions (equimolar ratio) as previously published [10]. The silanization of MNPs with ionic liquids based on amino acids is schematically shown in Scheme 2 with ideal conditions being that a monolayer is formed. The resulting MNPs materials obtained by reaction with ligands OH-Chol, Gly-Chol and Lys-Chol are denoted as Chol-MNPs, Gly-Chol-MNPs and Lys-Chol-MNPs, respectively. The reaction route depicted in Scheme 2 shows surface attachment by the formation of Fe−O−Si bonds, leading to monolayer (route 1). However, stabilization of the MNPs via hydrogen bond formation or by carboxylate interactions cannot be discarded. Water was used as solvent because the MNPs are well dispersible and the ligand shows high solubility. For comparison purposes MNPs were also reacted with an aqueous solution of commercially available hydroxide choline, [OH-(CH2)2 NMe3]+OH−, under similar experimental conditions and denoted as Chol-MNPs (com). FT-IR was used to verify the successful surface modification. Fig. 1 shows the FTIR spectrum of MNPs and ionic liquid stabilized MNPs. Since magnetite has an inverse spinel-type structure, it shows bands indicating the vibrations MT–O–MO (ν 1 ≈ 600–550 cm−1), MO O (ν 2 ≈ 470 cm−1), and MT–MO (ν 3 ≈ 350–400 cm−1), where MT and MO correspond to the metal occupying tetrahedral and octahedral positions, respectively. Both, ν 1 and ν 2 type bands are well defined. In addition, characteristic bands are observed at 3441 cm−1 assigned to OH stretching vibrations and the remaining physisorbed water molecules, at 1629 cm−1 due to deformation vibrations of the adsorbed water molecules. After surface modification, Chol-MNPs material displays additional bands due to the presence of the alkyl chain and the quaternary amine; at 2929 and 2878 cm−1 attributed to the ν(CH) stretching vibrations and at 1475 and 1449 cm−1 assigned to the bending vibrations of δ(CH). For free glycine, the main infrared bands are the νa (COO) and the νs (COO), located at 1596 and 1412 cm−1, respectively. For compound Gly-Chol, besides the bands at 1475 and 1449 cm−1 assigned to the bending vibrations of δ(CH), the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of the carboxylate group appear at 1581 and 1413 cm−1 making evident the protonation reaction of compound OH-Chol in the presence of glycine (see Fig. S4). In the Gly-Chol-MNPs material the same sequence of bands is shifted to 1628 (overlapped with physisorbed water) and 1478 cm−1, respectively. The material Lys-Chol-MNPs shows a similar pattern of bands for carboxylate group at 1629 and 1478 cm−1. The frequency due to asymmetric vibration mode increases whereas that due to symmetric vibrational mode decreases, indicating that the carboxylate group shows some type of coordination. (See Fig. S5 and S6). The UV–vis spectra of an aqueous diluted suspension of MNPs and stabilized MNPs with ionic liquid show significant absorbance in UV–vis with shoulders at 332 and 483 nm, indicative of the presence of iron oxide (Fig. S7). In comparison to non-stabilized magnetite nanoparticles there is a slight blue shift upon the use of ionic liquids as capped ligands [14]. The diffuse reflectance DRUV-Vis spectrum of iron based hydroxides/oxides can be separated into different regions based on absorptions; ligand to metal charge transfer along with contribution of Fe3+ ligand field transition; pair excitation process of magnetically coupled Fe3+ ions and two strong absorption bands near 640 and 900 nm of ligand field transitions of Fe3+ cation in octahedral environment [15]. In the range measured from 200 to 800 nm, magnetite nanoparticles spectrum (Fig. 2 ) shows a strong absorption band envelope centred at 345 nm, which represents transitions between the oxygen non-bonding and metal d-orbitals (VB*to CF) of both octahedral and tetrahedral ions. As can be seen in Fig. 2, the silanization process to give the materials Chol-MNPs and Lys-Chol-MNPs does not provide any extra absorption bands, probably because the expected electronic transitions for choline and lysine groups are overlapped with this broad band. X-ray diffraction patterns of the synthesized MNPs samples (Fig. 3 ) show a diffraction pattern characteristic of the spinel structure of magnetite (Fe3O4). Peaks at 2θ equal to 30.1°, 35.4°, 43.1°, 53.4°, 57.1°, and 62.6° can be indexed as (220), (311), (400), (511), and (440) lattice planes of cubic magnetite, respectively (JCPDS 19–629). However, and considering the typically small differences between typical XRD patterns for magnetite and maghemite, these two phases may be hardly distinguishable in such an intimate mixture. No clear reflection peak due to other crystalline phases, which could have occured as impurity, was observed, indicating that final products were pure enough, from this point of view, consisting essentially of a binary mixture of the two spinel magnetic iron oxides, namely magnetite and maghemite. The materials Chol-MNPs, Gly-Chol-MNPs, Lys-Chol-MNPs and Chol-MNPs (com) showed typical Fe3O4 diﬀ ; ;raction peaks at 35.8⁰ corresponding to the (311) planes after surface modification indicating surface functionalization did not change the crystal structure of the nanoparticles. Nevertheless, the diffractogram of Gly-Chol-MNPs material shows additional peaks probably due to the presence of the glycinate group. The intensities of the reflection peaks in these X-ray diffraction patterns for the samples Chol-MNPs, Gly-Chol-MNPs and Lys-Chol-MNPs are in general smaller than those for pristine MNPs and Chol-MNPs (com). This means that the surface-silane agent tends to hinder the growth of the nanoparticles, keeping them in a monodispersed state. The line broadening observed is essentially due to the nanoparticle size effect which indicates that MNPs have small particle sizes. The crystallite size of MNPs and stabilized MNPs was calculated by applying the Debye-Scherrer equation (Dhkl =  0.9λ/(βcosθ)), in which β stands for the half-width of the XRD diﬀ ; ;raction line, θ is the peak position in angles and λ is the CuKα radiation wavelength, 1.54056 Å, to the reflection peak (311) (See Table 1 ). As can be seen, the silanization process increases particle size meanwhile the iron oxide nanoparticles reacted with [OH(CH2)2 NMe3]+OH− maintaining their size. Such crystallite size approximately corresponds to the TEM average size of particles, which indicates a monocrystalline nature of the particles. Fig. 4 shows some TEM images for MNPs and ionic liquid stabilized MNPs. The average size of MNPs was 8.6 nm and 10.5 nm in the case of Lys-Chol-MNPs material. Based on the nitrogen content obtained by elemental analysis the quantity of molecules attached to the MNPS was calculated to be 0.40 mmol g−1 for Chol-MNPs, 0.38 mmol g−1 for Gly-Chol-MNPs and 0.25 mmol g−1 for Lys-Chol-MNPs. TGA measurements presented in Fig. 5 indicate a significant total weight loss for Lys-Chol-MNPs and Chol-MNPs, 10.6 and 12.6%, respectively. The weight loss between 25 °C and 100 °C can be attributed to physisorbed water. The subsequent losses between 100 °C and 450 °C are attributed to the silane ligands based on choline ionic liquid. As can be seen, Lys-Chol-MNPs shows two consecutive mass losses, from 100 to 200 °C probably due to amino acid fragmentation and from 200 to 450 °C due to alkyl chain degradation. At 450 °C the weight is stabilized suggesting that the remaining mass of about 82% could be attributed to the magnetite content. In this section the electrochemical behaviour of pristine iron oxide nanoparticles (MNPs), magnetic nanoparticles stabilized with the ionic liquid based on glycine amino acid (Gly-Chol-MNPs) and for comparison purposes stabilized with the commercial hydroxide choline (Chol-MNPs (com)) were studied by means of differential pulse voltammetry and cyclic voltammetry. The experiments were carried out at room temperature, using a three-electrode-single compartment electrochemical cell. A modified carbon paste electrode (MCPE) or a film modified glassy carbon electrode with embedded nanoparticles were used as working electrodes, an Ag/AgCl/KCl (3 M) as reference electrode and a platinum rod as counter electrode. The electrolyte chosen was a buffer phosphate solution (pH 6.4) since the slightly acid pH avoids the formation of non-soluble iron oxides species and hence prevents additional adsorption phenomenon onto the electrode surface. The measurements were recorded immediately after immersion of the fresh electrode surface into the electrolyte aqueous solution or at short times as indicated. Fig. 6 A shows the DPV recorded for three different electrodes prepared with non-coated Fe3O4 nanoparticles, Gly-Chol-MNPs and Chol-MNPs (com). In the cathodic scan (from 1.0 to −1.75 V) of MNPs recorded at 75 V of Modulation Amplitude the current peak increases abruptly around −0.3 V rendering a broad reduction peak formed by the overlapping of two different reduction peaks at −0.36 and −0.56 V. The peak intensity current of this reproducible signal decreases when the modulation amplitude value decreases to 25 V. As previously published by Zhu et al. [16], these two cathodic peaks can be attributed to Fe(III) reduction within the solid state. Since magnetite is an inverse spinel with Fe(III) in tetrahedral and octahedral sites and Fe(II) in octahedral sites, the experimental results support the one electron reduction process of Fe(III) with different coordination environments. On the reverse scan (Fig. 6B) (from −1.5 to 0.9 V) which was recorded in an anodic mode after cathodic polarization of the electrode, three peaks are observed at −0.75, −0.55 and −0.35 V, indicating the existence of several oxidation processes on the electrode surface: the re-oxidation of electrochemically generated Fe(II) in the previous cathodic scan, the oxidation of Fe(II) to Fe (III) leading to the conversion of magnetite to maghemite (Fe2O3) and finally, the oxidation of dissolved Fe(II) ions. The coating of magnetite nanoparticles with the ionic liquid greatly influences the redox behaviour of this material. As can be seen, after silanization the broad signal attributed to Fe(III) reduction processes disappears because of coating. Similarly, the anodic differential pulse voltammogram is silent in the range expected for Fe(II)/Fe(III) oxidation processes which demonstrates the efficient silanization process of the iron oxide nanoparticles which isolates the iron species and prevents redox processes in slightly acidic aqueous media. The electrochemical response of Gly-Chol-MNPs in not time dependant, at least at short time periods, and can be related to the existence of a silane ligand coating protecting the magnetite nanoparticles and avoiding oxidation and extra re-dissolution of iron species as we have previously observed [17]. The stabilization efficiency obtained with [OH-(CH2)2 NMe3]+OH− is lower than those obtained with the silane ionic liquid with the amino acid functionality. The existence in the reduction scan of a broad signal at similar reduction potential to that previously observed with MNPs supports the reduction process of Fe(III) on the MNPS surface. Nevertheless, these results suggest the growth of a coated layer on the iron oxide nanoparticles, since the reduction process is not as much efficient as in MNPs, as demonstrated by the less intense signal attributed to the reduction of Fe(III) and the fact that the anodic differential pulse voltammogram is also silent. Cyclic voltammetry measurements support this behaviour (Fig. 7 ), this technique less sensitive than DPV, shows in the case of Gly-Chol-MNPs and Chol-MNPs (com), the absence of redox processes in the scan range imposed by the electrolyte aqueous solution but in non-coated MNPS a broad cathodic peak centred at −0.70 V is observed with an anodic peak associated to the former peak at −0.07 V (Fig. 7 and Fig. S8). 3.2 Catalytic tests The ionic liquid stabilized magnetic nanoparticles were tested in knoevenagel condensation between benzaldehyde and malononitrile or ethyl cyanoacetate in ethanol as solvent and at room temperature. The reaction was monitored by GC and the products obtained were analysed by 1H NMR spectroscopy (see Fig. S9). The results (Table 2 ) show quantitative conversion and nearly quantitative selectivity after 30 min, for all the materials based on MNPs stabilized by ionic liquid when using malononitrile as reactant (Entries 1–4). These catalysts present higher activity than imidazolium cation-based ionic liquid functionalized silica gel [18], which provided 93.1 yield after 4 h reaction time and at 100 °C. Xu et al. [19] prepared an effective solid base catalyst, microporous graphitic carbon nitride, which exhibited 87.1% conversion after 4 h and at 90 °C using CH3CN as solvent. When using the less activated ethyl cyanoacetate, Chol-MNPs material show highest activity, 84% conversion and 99% selectivity towards ethyl 2-cyano-3-phenylacrylate (Entry 5). A similar result was obtained using niobiosilicates of SBA-15 functionalized with imidazole, where niobium species located in silica are active centres in the Knoevenagel condensation reaction [20]. As can be seen in Table 2, better conversion values are obtained by using Chol-MNPs (Entry 5) against Lys-Chol-MNPs (Entry 9) and Gly-Chol-MNPs (Entry 10). These results contrast with the results obtained by Calvino-Casilda and co-workers [21]. They observed that choline hydroxide ionic liquid, [Chol][OH], gave lower conversion values than those obtained with [Chol][Gly] or [Chol][Ala]. Even when the basicity demand of the methylene compound increases, the conversion values obtained with [Chol][OH] are less than half of those provided by [Chol][Gly] or [Chol][Ala]. There are no appreciable differences between Gly-Chol-MNPs and Lys-Chol-MNPs, 67% and 65% of conversion, respectively, suggesting that the influence of the amino acid fragment is not crucial at this stage. Although they present different pK a values (Gly(pK a2 ) = 9.8 and Lys(pK a2 ) = 9.1), they both possess enough basic strength to abstract the proton from the methylene group of ethyl cyanoacetate (pK a  = 9) and steric hindrance imposed by the side chain seems not to be a determinant factor as contrary observed in the work cited above. The iron oxide nanoparticles stabilized with commercial choline hydroxide aqueous solution (Chol-MNPs (com)) shows lower conversion value (79% conversion, Entry 7) in comparison to Chol-MNPs synthesized in this work (84% conversion, Entry 5), demonstrating that both the use of a long alkyl chain silane ligand to stabilize the magnetic nanoparticles and the choline hydroxide functionality seems to have a synergic effect in Chol-MNPs material activity as catalyst. The reaction has been also performed with Chol-MNPs in the absence of solvent (Entry 6), observing an important decrease in the yield of the reaction. Additionally, the heterogenization effect of amino acid based silane ionic liquid has also been tested using Gly-Chol (Entry 8). As expected, a decrease in activity upon immobilization (from 88% conversion for Gly-Chol to 67% conversion for Gly-Chol-MNPs). Based on our preliminary results [22] for the material Chol-MNPs we propose the ion-par mechanism. This mechanism involves base abstraction of a proton from the methylene carbon and the formation of a carbanion, which attacks the carbonyl group forming an enol. The reaction ends with the formation of a double CC bond and water release. It is accepted, that the Knoevenagel condensation of aldehydes with malonates possessing acidic carbon-hydrogen bond catalyzed by amines can proceed via ion-pair or imine intermediate mechanisms [23,24]. The last mechanism involves the formation a covalent imine intermediate with the base group. Both mechanisms have been accepted for reactions catalyzed by amino acid ligands [21,25]. In amorphous silica Angeletti et al. [26] proposed the involvement of neighbouring silanol groups through the formation of hydrogen bonds and the improvement of reaction rate by strongly adsorbing water molecules produced by the reaction. In the case of using primary amines as basic functionalities, Zhang et al. [27] proposed that silanol groups, with low pK a value, can transfer a proton influencing greatly the mechanism through the formation of an imine intermediate. In our materials, the presence of a hydroxyl group attached to the main alkyl chain could similarly influence the mechanism through the formation of the imine intermediate or favouring hydrogen bonds formation with release of water and enhancement of the nucleophilic addition of the anionic methylene compound. In addition, the use of hydrophilic magnetic nanoparticles would improve the anion stabilization. Thus, the ion-pair mechanism suggests for Lys-Chol-MNPs and Gly-Chol-MNPs materials is shown in Scheme 3 . As can be seen, the amine group of the amino acid abstracts the proton from the methylene group of malononitrile or ethyl cyanoacetate to form the corresponding carbanion. The carbanion attacks the carbonyl group of the benzaldehyde yielding an enol which capture the proton of the catalyst to obtain the corresponding product and the regenerated catalyst. The reusability of Chol-MNPs catalyst was studied for Knoevenagel condensation of benzaldehyde and malononitrile. The catalyst was easily recovered under an external magnetic field (see Fig. S10). The results of malononitrile conversion and selectivity towards 2-benzylidenemalononitrile for six consecutive catalytic runs are shown in Fig. 8 , where it is observed that both parameters remain practically unaltered with practically quantitative conversion of malononitrile to 2-benzylidenemalononitrile and yield of corresponding product in comparison to fresh catalyst. The reusability value of Chol-MNPs catalyst is consistent with good chemical resistance of the structure against the reaction conditions. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have synthesized magnetic nanoparticles materials stabilized by ionic liquid based silanes possessing choline hydroxide or amino acid functionalities to protect them from re-agglomeration, resulting in smaller and better-dispersed particles. These materials have been fully characterized and the iron oxide nanoparticles stabilization has been demonstrated by solid state voltammetry techniques. The conversion of iron oxide nanoparticles in hydrophilic materials makes them suitable as active catalysts in Knoevenagel heterogeneous condensation at room temperature. The catalyst Chol-MNPs with hydroxide choline units showed higher activity than the catalysts with choline amino acids Gly-Chol-MNPs and Lys-Chol-MNPs in Knoevenagel condensation between benzaldehyde and ethy cyanoacetate. In addition, Chol-MNPs with a highly chemical stable function and a strong base is a reusable catalyst that can be employed several times without loss of activity. coredata.dc:description: Iron oxide magnetic nanoparticles (MNPs) stabilized with silane ligands, containing choline hydroxide and amino acid ionic liquid functionalities, have been prepared. The appropriate silane ligands have been synthesized; the choline hydroxide propyl silane ligand in a process inspired in the industrial production of choline hydroxide and the amino acid ionic liquids in a straight forward acid-base process using the former compound. The synthesized materials have been fully characterized by elemental analysis, X-ray diffraction (XRD), fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRUV-vis), thermogravimetric analysis (TG-DTG), N2 adsorption-desorption, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and voltammetry solid state techniques. Ionic liquid stabilized magnetic nanoparticles have been very effective as heterogeneous basic catalysts in Knoevenagel condensation reaction at room temperature. The catalyst containing choline hydroxide ionic liquid (Chol-MNPs) exhibited highest catalytic activity and can easily be recovered under an external magnetic field and subsequently reused several times.
coredata.dc:title: Silanization of Iron Oxide Magnetic Nanoparticles with ionic liquids based on amino acids and its application as heterogeneous catalysts for Knoevenagel condensation reactions
